_prev_prog_3.Description: Ennis-Flint stores 30% aqua ammonia in a 15,000-gallon bulk storage vessel, which is held to an administrative limit of 13,050 gallons.  The amount is greater than the listed threshold quantity of 20,000 pounds for aqua ammonia established in 40 CFR 68.130.  Since the aqua ammonia does not exceed the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM)-listed minimum concentration of 44% and the facility is not one of the listed NAICS codes per 40 CFR 68.10(d)(1), the process could potentially be eligible for RMP Program 2.  However, since Ennis-Flint complies with RMP Program 3 and the OSHA PSM standard other processes at their facilities, Ennis-Flint has voluntarily opted to comply with the Program 3 requirements under 40 CFR 68 Subpart D for the aqua ammonia process.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This is an executive summary of the policies, procedures and activities for compliance with the EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Requirements - Risk Management Program pursuant to Title 40 Part 68 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR 68) for Ennis-Flint, Inc.'s facility in High Point, North Carolina (High Point facility).



The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source:  Ennis-Flint adheres to the Federal and State regulations and is in compliance with the RMP requirements for handling of aqua ammonia.  Employees of the facility are trained in their roles and responsibilities in implementing prevention and emergency response.  Should an emergency occur, Ennis-Flint will follow the Contingency Plan.



The stationary source and regulated substances handled:  Aqua ammonia is stored in a bulk tank at the facility.  Aqua ammonia is used in the manufacturing of latex polymer.



The general accidental release prevention program and chemical specific prevention steps:  The Ennis-Flint High Point facility has implemented the Program Level 3 prevention program requirements under the RMP regulations.  The required elements of the RMP prevention program are listed below:



?    Employee Participation

?    Process Safety Information

?    Process Hazard Analysis

?    Operating Procedures

?    Training

?    Contractors

?    Pre-startup Safety Review

?    Mechanical Integrity

?    Hot Work Permit

?    Management of Change

?    Incident Investigation

?    Compliance Audits



In addition, the facility meets the requirements of the RMP Emergency Planning and Response element as detailed below. These items, their specific requirements, and how the Ennis-Flint High Point facility complies with the requirements are addressed in the procedural documents.



The five-year accident history:  The Ennis-Flint High Point facility has had zero RMP reportable incidents in the previous five years.



The emergency response program:  In the event of an emergency,

the facility personnel will be alerted to the incident, the area will be evacuated, the onsite emergency contact will be contacted, HAZ-MAT Environmental Services will be contacted, the High Point fire department will be contacted and the appropriate agencies will be notified of a release to the environment.  Additional details related to emergency procedures can be located in the facility's Contingency Plan.



Planned changes to improve safety:  The facility will train their employees on an ongoing basis.  The safety systems and preventive measures are constantly evaluated and improved. This facility also expects to improve safety performance by emphasizing all elements of the RMP program.  All recommendations during the Process Hazard Analysis were designed to improve the safety performance of the ammonia process.  Ennis-Flint will evaluate each recommendation in a timely manner and implement, as soon as possible, those recommendations that will reduce the possibility of a release and/or mitigate the consequences of an unintentional release.
